DRY LUMBER

MOORE & MACDOWALL

Wish to inform the Public that they have on hand and for sale a Half Million Feet of Dry Lumber, consisting of Matched, Dressed and Undressed.

Dressed Flooring, $48
Undressed do., 42
Dressed Siding, 48
Undressed do., 42
Sheeting, 30
Common Lumber, 35
Dimension do., 40

Lath, 75 cts. per bundle.
Shingles, $6.50 per M.

We are prepared to Contract for Buildings as cheaply as any firm in Town.

Builders paying Cash or giving good security for LARGE Orders, will have a reduction made.

MOORE & MACDOWALL.
The comptroller proposed "The Mayors Corporation," and in compounding the vote with Mr. Macintosh, he placed him both as mayor and as a successful politician. Judge Macintosh, Mr. Macintosh was very proper and polite in doing so referred to some of the elders of the corporation. He also assured the members of the corporation that he would be attentive to the importance of the society. Mr. Stewart also made a few remarks in reply.

Mr. Adams proposed "The Newcastle Exhibitors and Mr. Charles Robertson replied and referred to his own experience in the same line of business, next in Ontario, latterly in the North-West—his case being that he had been engaged in the same line there and anywhere else he had lived.

The comptroller proposed "The Judges," and Mr. Conner, Capt. Hoey replied, and pointed out that they had been engaged in a decided success over all. In his own opinion, he thought that the judges, since very fine animals had been exhibited, and he wished to say his colleagues had done their work harmoniously, and he trusted they had been appreciated by the exhibitors. Others followed and endorsed the captain's remarks.

It had given him great pleasure to be present at such an occasion, and spoke of the excellence of the meat and vegetables. He also complimented Mr. Miller who had been successful in promoting the exhibition, and thought there was an indication of progress which was very encouraging.

Mr. Clark then kindly spoke proposed "The Newcastle Exhibitors," and it was with the name of Mr. Wm. Miller, who had been the great interest behind taken in the affair, and who had been the historian of other. Mr. Miller kindly replied and expressed his thanks for the speeches.

The next stage of the proceedings was the announcement of the prizes. After the presentation, the chairman politely brought this successful meeting to a close. It was evident that many of those who had a long way to travel found the meeting very interesting. The principles, but there was no doubt that the exhibition had been present appeared to enjoy the meeting.

There took off his several way

And now open and ready for inspection.

BETTS & Gwynne.

ESTABLISHED: 1879.
